title: Judgment on Israel's Sin
shortSummary: Amos 4 presents a prophetic indictment against the wealthy women of Samaria and the nation of Israel for their oppression and persistent rebellion against God. Despite repeated judgments and warnings, Israel refuses to repent, prompting a solemn call to prepare to meet God. This chapter highlights God's holiness, justice, and sovereign control over nature and history.
timeline: c. 760-750 BC - Ministry of Amos during the reign of Jeroboam II in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Amos
keyCharacters.description: The prophet delivering God's message of judgment against Israel for their social injustice and spiritual rebellion.

keyCharacters.name: Women of Samaria (Kine of Bashan)
keyCharacters.description: Symbolic representation of the wealthy and indulgent women who oppress the poor and ignore God's warnings.

definitions.definition: A metaphor referring to well-fed, pampered cows from the fertile region of Bashan, symbolizing the wealthy women of Samaria who oppress the poor.
Small hooks used for fishing, here symbolizing the means by which God will capture and exile the people.
Important religious centers in Israel where people performed sacrifices and worship, often associated with apostasy in Amos' time.
A type of locust or caterpillar that devastates crops, used here as a symbol of divine judgment on Israel's agriculture.

outline.heading: Condemnation of the Oppressive Women
outline.description: Amos condemns the wealthy women of Samaria for their luxurious oppression of the poor, warning that God will bring judgment and exile upon them.

outline.heading: Call to Repentance and False Worship
outline.description: God rebukes Israel for their hypocritical religious practices at Bethel and Gilgal, where they multiply transgressions and offer insincere sacrifices.

outline.heading: God’s Repeated Judgments and Israel’s Stubbornness
outline.description: A catalogue of divine punishments including famine, drought, pestilence, and military defeat is recounted, yet Israel refuses to return to God.

outline.heading: The Call to Prepare to Meet God
outline.description: Because of Israel’s persistent rebellion, God declares that judgment is imminent and commands the nation to prepare to meet Him.

outline.heading: God’s Sovereignty Over Creation
outline.description: The chapter concludes by affirming God’s power as Creator and sovereign ruler, who controls nature and reveals His thoughts to mankind.

application: Examine your heart for any complacency or oppression towards others and seek to live justly and humbly before God.
Avoid empty religious rituals; instead, cultivate genuine repentance and obedience to God’s commands.
Recognize God’s sovereign control over all circumstances and respond to His discipline with a repentant heart.
Prepare daily to meet God by living in reverent awe of His holiness and authority.

keyVerses.text: Hear this word, ye kine of Bashan, that are in the mountain of Samaria, which oppress the poor, which crush the needy, which say to their masters, Bring, and let us drink.
keyVerses.significance: This verse vividly exposes the pride and oppression of Israel’s elite, setting the tone for God’s judgment.

keyVerses.text: And I also have given you cleanness of teeth in all your cities, and want of bread in all your places: yet have ye not returned unto me, saith the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: God’s repeated judgments are meant to bring Israel to repentance, but their stubbornness highlights the danger of hardening one’s heart.

keyVerses.text: Therefore thus will I do unto thee, O Israel: and because I will do this unto thee, prepare to meet thy God, O Israel.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning that judgment is certain and imminent, calling for serious preparation to stand before God.

keyVerses.text: For, lo, he that formeth the mountains, and createth the wind, and declareth unto man what is his thought, that maketh the morning darkness, and treadeth upon the high places of the earth, The LORD, The God of hosts, is his name.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God’s supreme power over creation and His intimate knowledge of humanity, underscoring His authority to judge.
